clinical_study.brief_title: Associations Analysis Between Lifestyle and Osteoporosis
clinical_study.official_title: The Associations Analysis Between Lifestyle and Osteoporosis Among Chinese Population

lead_sponsor.agency: Shanghai Tongji Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: Shanghai Tongji Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: A large-scale, community-based, cross-sectional study was conducted to evaluate the extent to which lifestyle was associated with osteoporosis among the Chinese population by using self-reported questionnaire methods.

detailed_description.textblock: A large-scale, community-based, cross-sectional study was conducted to evaluate the extent to which lifestyle was associated with osteoporosis among the Chinese population by using self-reported questionnaire methods. More than 3000 participants were recruited in communities in Shanghai. Data involved in demographic information, lifestyle, dietary habits, medical history and clinical biomarkers were collected. Every participants were measured bone mineral density (BMD g/cm2) at calcaneus by standardized quantitative ultrasound (QUS, Hologic Inc., Bedford, MA, USA) utilizing T-scores based on WHO criteria. A standard statistical analysis including univariate and multiple variables regression analysis to explore the risk or preventive factors involved in Chinese lifestyle associated with osteoporosis.

primary_outcome.measure: osteoporosis accessed by Bone Mass Density (BMD)
primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be measured for the duration of outpatient stay, an expected average of 2 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The bone mineral density (BMD g/cm2) was measured at calcaneus by standardized quantitative ultrasound (QUS, Hologic Inc., Bedford, MA, USA) utilizing T-scores based on WHO criteria, which were obtained from the automated equipment. T-score refers to the ratio between patient's BMD and that of young adult population of same sex and ethnicity. T-score of > -1 was taken as normal, between -1 and -2.5 osteopenic and < -2.5 as osteoporotic.

clinical_study.condition: Osteoporosis of Disuse With Current Pathological Fracture

study_pop.textblock: We performed a risk-factor study for osteoporosis using a random sample of the Chinese population. Participants were recruited from rural and urban communities in Shanghai. Survey participants aged 30-90 years were included in this study.
